{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13636].
  {panel}


There are several reason it would be nice to be able to add a comment only to a version.

A save was made but a comment was forgotten.  It would be nice to just add one.

It would be a good way for document approval.  A person could go to the comments and mark their approval.  This is tracked in the history and would be useful to our use of Confluence.

Since everyone see the comment left it could be useful to be able to mark the status.  Havent edited a page for 2 day.  Big issue comes up and now I dont have time to work on this document a "On Hold" comment could be used to communicate a status.  If this was put in the comments below for the pages discussion, this message would be outdated and no longer useful once editing is resumed.
fields.summary: When editing a document it would be a good feature to let a comment count as an edit.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13634].
  {panel}

Please consider this as a feature request for a future release of Confluence.

Boolean operands on Space permissions would be awesome.  E.g. setup a Space that people in the LDAP group STAFF and the LDAP group Biosciences were the only people that were able to view/edit/add/etc - otherwise I have to have a group for "Staff in Biosiences", "Staff in Engineering", "Staff in Computing", etc.

Another use would be to add exclusions to Space permission, e.g. I want everyone in the Biosciences group to have full permissions on a Space, but *NOT* the users in the "Students in Biosciences" group as they should just be able to view.

One of the major gripes (in general, not specifically Confluence) is that they *HATE* having to set up permissions in different applications for the same groups of users.  We've gone some way in improving things by moving all of our Confluence group management to LDAP, but I think this functionality would make things even better.

Although we've moved all of our group management to LDAP I can see this being useful for people who are using confluence-groups and those that are using a mixture of confluence-groups and LDAP.

Boolean operands on group/user membership is phenomenally powerful and would put you miles ahead of anything else I've seen in terms of application permissions (and I'm not just talking wikis!!!).
fields.summary: Boolean operators on user and group management

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13601].
  {panel}

When a user tries to edit a page with an existing draft, any further changes will be applied to that draft not a separate draft. This means that a user will overwrite any changes saved in the existing draft with their new changes.

Confluence should either:
* Allow multiple drafts to be saved for the one user on any one page.
* Not allow the user to edit an page unless they have decided to resume editing or discard a draft.
* Notify the user that any new changes will overwrite the existing draft.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13537].
  {panel}

At the moment, only the last word typed in the quick nav is used as a prefix search with the remaining words will use a full text search.

For example, searching for _"doc conf"_ will locate _"confluence doc"_ while _"conf doc"_ will not. This will cause [some confusion|CONF-13192] with the quick nav as it isn't explicitly clear why the 2 searches come up with different results.

Having all the words use prefix search will create too much of a performance hit to be a viable option.

A good option is to implement autocompletion. For example, when typing in _"conf"_ the user will be prompted to complete the full text _"confluence"_, since there are no other pages that start with _"conf"_

This means that we can be fairly sure that the user will have entered the full text and there will be less confusion.
fields.summary: Autocompletion for Quick Nav

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13462].
  {panel}

Here's the scenario:

A user submitted a request from a Confluence page (containing a macro), which is submitted from the browser to Tomcat via HTTP. The requests (HTTP Connector) timed out after 2 minutes and Tomcat returns a [503 error|http://www.checkupdown.com/status/E503.html] to the browser. The database query however will still be executed.

A customer pointed out that the ability to cancel a request that takes unexpectedly long to complete - usually due to an error in page code - should be available to a page author or viewer.

A quote from the customer:
{quote}
Many is the time I have previewed a reporting macro invocation that I didn't want to complete, or tried to troubleshoot a user's problem and been stymied because editing the page required me to view it first, and the 503 message didn't allow the page to render so that I could click its edit link. I know, of course, that I could look up its content ID and invoke the editpage action independently, but that's time-consuming and irritating.

And, of course, 503 (service unavailable) is not what I would think of as an appropriate response to something that was taking too long to complete, though of course there may not be any other conclusion the respondant server could reach under the circumstances.

But in the final analysis I still can't imagine a case where a transaction - at least, one whose only purpose is to provide a response with no persistent side effect - should be allowed to continue after it is known for certain that the requestor will never receive that response. This is especially important when the user's most likely action in the face of such a situation is to try it again - often multiple times - raising the probability of deadlocks, delays and wasted resources that can build to performance-affecting - and even service-threatening - levels to near certainty.

Even for an action that does have persistent side effects, I would not find it acceptable to be uncertain of whether they had been executed under such conditions. If there is a meaningful risk that it may take unreasonably long to complete, it would be more sensible to use job scheduling to put it explicitly into the background, with the ability to monitor its state. 
{quote}

An interface that indicates running queries or actions might also be helpful in this case.
fields.summary: Admin configuration for database query/transaction timeouts

A subset of our Confluence user community has recently expressed their desire to have, after clicking the print button, the option to have all attachments included with the print. I think that the headings in Confluence are too hard to distinguish from one another.

The difference between e.g. heading 1 and heading 2 seems to be maybe 2 pixels in the font size, while they're both bold and underlined. This makes it impossible to see which one is which when scrolling through a document.

Same thing with heading 3, 4 and 5: there's only a slight variation in font size that makes them different from each other.

On a side note, I know that many people think that heading 1 is too big and takes up too much space, and are using heading 5 as their main heading.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13308].
  {panel}

Taken from [http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-13277]

According to this document, [http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Restoring+a+Deleted+Page], and every version of this document in past versions of Confluence:

    When you restore a page, you are retrieving it from 'Trash' to the same location in the space where it existed before it was deleted.

This is not the case. When you restore a page, the page is restored to the root of the space, not to it's original location. Example: spaceroot > First > Second > Third. If you delete Second and then restore, Second is now located at spaceroot > Second.


It would be much better if the deleted page was restored to it's original location.  Note that when this change is made, CONF-13277 should be updated to ensure that the documentation correctly describes the actual behaviour.
fields.summary: Restoring a deleted page should restore it to the original location

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13294].
  {panel}

Create a way for Confluence to remember its JVM parameters or previous settings (eg. LDAP) so that the same parameters or configurations do not need to be added/applied again in the upgraded version.

At the moment when one sets a JVM parameter for Confluence, eg. Xmx, permgen, etc. the value will not be carried over to the new upgraded version. The same goes for Confluence settings eg. *atlassian-user.xml* this has to be done manually all over again.

A customer gave a good comment on this matter:
{quote}
I now realize we went through this same support issue before! Increasing permgen size. 

You can search our history. But what happened is that it was lost in the upgrade (we didn't merge it over). 
:
:
Although the way Conf/JIRA upgrades are done is our #1 complaint about Conf/JIRA. The upgrade process is so painful we dread doing Conf/JIRA upgrades and put them off for six months or a year sometimes. 

_Having to hand merge over files seems completely anachronistic._ 

Settings like permgensize and database and user authentication should live _OUTSIDE_ the install folder and thus should survive an upgrade. It is hard to comprehend the way you do it, how people accept merging that stuff over by hand even for the most minor upgrade. It makes for a horrible user experience.

The bottom line is you probably expect IT professional will admin this stuff. We are software engineers but not IT professional. So our expectations are very different. I would expect an upgrade to be automatic and never required hand editing anything.
:
:
Those are our standing complaints: upgrades and memory settings. Once it's up and running we like Conf & JIRA, they are good products overall, just the admin/install part is lacking.
{quote}
fields.summary: Remember previous  version's JVM parameters and other Confluence settings so that an admin does not need to reapply the settings again in the upgraded version

Regarding Confluence configuration at Administration -> General -> Security and privacy settings -> User email visibility 

It would increase privacy of users, if a supplementary option "show to logged-in users only" were available to restrict display of email addresses (masked or public, depending on the current setting) to users who are logged-in.

Maybe options regarding email addresses should be divided into a) how email addresses are displayed (clear, masked, scrambled, not), and b) to whom (everyone, administrators, users, a specific user group, none)

This should in particular work with external user management.

Thanks,
Torge

PS JIRA since version 3.2 has such an option?

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13259].
  {panel}

Add an access control for spaces that controls if its contents can show up in search results.
If a user has search rights but no view rights to the space it's contents can show up in search results, but the resulting documents will not be viewable.
If a user has search and view rights to the space it's contents can show up in search results, and the resulting documents will be viewable.
View rights by default will indicate that the user has search rights.
If a user has not search rights and no view rights the contents cannot show up in a search result.

The Confluence web interface for its page breadcrumb can be improved. 

When opening a page with a long breadcrumb (for example on a laptop monitor or small monitor) the breadcrumb section will be dynamically arranged (a scroll bar will appear and the breadcrumb items will be moved down). 

Perhaps instead of using a scrollbar (not pretty) we can truncate the breadcrumbs with a '...'

Steps to replicate:
# Open a page with long breadcrumb link, for example: http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/D
# Minimise the browser, keep minimising the window until you see the page breadcrumb is dynamically arranged.
# You will then see the breadcrumb items moved downwards and a scrollbar will appear.

Would not it be wonderful if we had a single point of access of Administering multiple Confluence upgrades, plugin installs etc...

For example this 'Application Manager' would be able to retrieve a plugin from a Plugin Repo and then by {{deploy}} command would deploy it to all (or selected) confluence instances. Similarly, one could disable all plugins from this single point access. 

Clearly, there is _endless_ options for managing the application {{r e m o t e l y}} (if you want to call that)

Could be useful for large deployments .... and am not saying that architecture wise or implementation wise this is an easy task !!! Not at all :-) Yet think of the potential possibilities .....

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12970].
  {panel}

It could be useful to have a functionality to be able to verify the following:
* Access permission to daily backup
* Sufficient space left on drive
* Accessibility and existence  (is the directory on a NAS or Virtual Mapped Drive)

Simple test could run these three tests and provide feedback within the admin screen.

One could take it one step further and add a functionality to check the number of backups created in the directory and delete ones that are *X* days old to clear some space for new backups. Or/And move these backups into an archive and store them away on a 'cheap' Hardisk on a slow&old machine. Keep the expensive one for the good stuff :-)
fields.summary: Verification of daily backup directory
Allow/Add ability to have custom plugin objects be sized and viewed in the wysiwyg editor window like an image.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12964].
  {panel}

Hi all,

I would like to use the user name and the update/creation date of a page and display it in another page, is there a way to do this?

Example of use:
The user A creates:
 - a page P1 with the label 'project_01' on 09/03.
 - a page P2 with the label 'project_01' on 09/04.
 - a page P3 with the label 'project_02' on 09/04.

The user B creates another page which list in a table the pages with 'project_01' as label. The first column = page name, the second column = user name and the third column = update date.

We should get this:
||Page name||user name||update date||
|P1|A|09/03|
|P2|B|09/04|

Thanks a lot and regards,
Stephane
fields.summary: displaying of an user ID from a page to another page
